ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: In terms of practical skills, I learned a lot in terms of working with a manuscript and struggling with issues of translation (especially when the text itself is also a translation). In terms of knowledge I was able to learn a lot about Evagrius' worldview and his hermeneutic methods for interpreting scripturesscriptures, which directly related to my particular research interests.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The course was very successful. Reading through the manuscript and discussing the exegetical techniques of Evagrius but also thinking about issues of translation, the transmission of ideas, producing critical editions, and learning how to work with a manuscript were especially meaningful.
It was a good chance to engage with Christian Arabic manuscripts

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Would definitely recommend to anyone interested in Christian Arabic texts and monastic ideas/theology in particular.
